items.title: Google expands NotebookLM Plus to individual users
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Google has expanded [NotebookLM Plus](https://notebooklm.google/plus) to individual users with a Google One AI Premium subscription after its initial enterprise rollout.
- The subscription costs $20 per month, offering features such as 5 times the usage of the free version, 500 notebooks, and up to 500 chat queries daily.
- A 50% discount is available for U.S. students over 18, reducing the subscription to $9.99.
- The service allows for podcast-like audio generation based on uploaded content, with plans to introduce support for additional languages.
- Google has seen significant interest, particularly from students, and aims to keep the free version competitive while expanding paid features.

items.title: Bird cuts 120 jobs as part of ‘strategic realignment’
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Bird has cut 120 jobs, about one-third of its workforce, to realign operations amid AI growth.
- The layoffs were confirmed by CEO Robert Vis and communicated to impacted employees last Friday.
- This follows a previous cut of 90 jobs a year ago during the company's rebranding.
- Bird aims to position teams closer to customers in the Americas and Asia, expanding its market reach.
- The layoffs were said not to focus on cost reductions; instead, they reflect changes driven by AI integration.
- Affected employees will receive transition support, specific severance details were not disclosed.
- Key customers include Meta, PayPal, Square, and Uber, and the startup focuses on multi-channel communication solutions.

items.title: OpenAI spoke to government officials about its DeepSeek probe
items.author: Chris Lehane
items.summary:
- OpenAI has communicated with government officials regarding its investigation into DeepSeek.
- The company claims that DeepSeek improperly used data from OpenAI’s API to train its AI models.
- OpenAI's chief global affairs officer, Chris Lehane, defended their practices by comparing them to reading library books, contrasting them with DeepSeek's alleged misconduct of reselling content as original.
- OpenAI faces criticism for its approach to copyright issues, as it is being sued by several publishers for similar practices.

items.title: [TikTok](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=tiktok) wants Android users to sideload its app
items.summary:
- TikTok encourages Android users to sideload its app amidst uncertainty about its future in the U.S.
- The app is available for direct download at [TikTok.com/download](https://pollinations.ai/referral?topic=apk) as an APK file.
- This move allows TikTok to bypass the current app store ban while enforcement is paused.

items.title: Apple fixes iPhone and iPad bug used in an ‘extremely sophisticated attack’
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- On February 10, 2025, Apple released updates for iOS 18.3.1 and iPadOS 18.3.1 addressing a security flaw potentially exploited in targeted attacks.
- The vulnerability allowed disabling USB Restricted Mode on locked devices, which blocks data transfer via USB connections if the device remains locked for over seven days.
- Security researchers suggest the attack required physical access to use forensic tools like Cellebrite or Graykey.

items.title: Macron urges Europe to simplify its regulations to get back into the AI race
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- French President Emmanuel Macron announced a €109 billion investment package for the French AI ecosystem at the Artificial Intelligence Action Summit in Paris.
- He emphasized the need for a unified European strategy to simplify regulations and enhance AI investments.
- Macron called for European companies to preferentially support local startups, contrasting it with U.S. and Chinese practices.
- A statement from global leaders and tech CEOs is expected at the summit, focusing on AI regulation priorities.

items.title: Rivian opens commercial van sales to all businesses
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Rivian now sells commercial electric vans to any U.S. business, more than a year after ending its exclusivity deal with Amazon.
- The company offers two models: the smaller 500 and the larger 700, available only to registered businesses.
- This launch opens a new potential revenue stream for Rivian as they prepare for a more affordable SUV release in 2024.
- Amazon has 20,000 Rivian vans in their fleet, following a substantial investment and a previous order of 100,000 vehicles.

items.title: Perplexity’s Super Bowl ‘tweet’ increased app installs by 50%
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Perplexity opted for a tweet instead of a Super Bowl ad, increasing app installs by roughly 50%.
- Users needed to download the app and ask five questions during the Super Bowl to enter a $1 million contest.
- App downloads rose to 45,000 on Sunday, up from a daily average of around 30,000, helped boost its ranking in the App Store.

items.title: Mistral gets down to business
items.summary:
- Hundreds of heads of states and tech CEOs attended the [Artificial Intelligence Action Summit](https://techcrunch.com/tag/france-ai-action-summit/) in Paris.
- Mistral, a leading AI company in Europe, has raised over $1 billion and aims to shift focus from science to enterprise solutions.
- Launched AI assistant 'Le Chat' for iOS and Android, with support from French President Emmanuel Macron.
- Mistral partners with various organizations, including France Travail and Veolia, to enhance efficiency and job-seeking services.
- CEO Arthur Mensch highlights plans for an AI data center investment in Essonne to enhance system training capabilities.

items.title: Revel nabs $60M in New York State funding to build more EV chargers
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
• Revel secured a $60 million loan from NY Green Bank to expand its EV charging network in NYC.
• This loan marks the first investment by NY Green Bank in EV charging infrastructure.
• The funding will allow Revel to build nine new sites, adding 267 fast-charging stalls by 2027, with five sites planned to be completed within the next 12 months.
• Upcoming sites include charging stations at JFK and La Guardia airports.
• The Maspeth station will feature 60 stalls, making it one of the largest in the country.
• New York State mandates all new light-duty passenger vehicles to be zero emissions by 2035.
• Revel is also seeking to expand into California, aiming to launch a site in the Bay Area soon.

items.title: Tech giants and startups join forces to call for simpler EU rules on AI, data
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- 60 European companies launched the EU AI Champions Initiative during the AI Summit in Paris.
- The initiative aims to simplify Europe’s AI regulations and enhance leadership in the field.
- Led by General Catalyst, the initiative seeks to reduce regulatory complexities which hinder AI adoption.
- Key figures attending include French President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.
- The initiative emphasizes collaboration between established companies and startups in the European tech ecosystem.

items.title: Global police operation seizes 8base ransomware gang leak site
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- International law enforcement agencies seized the 8base ransomware gang's dark web leak site
- The operation involved agencies from Europe, Japan, U.S., and U.K., coordinated by the Bavarian State Criminal Police
- 8base is linked to RansomHouse and employs double-extortion tactics, demanding ransom while threatening to expose sensitive info
- The group targeted multiple sectors, especially healthcare, and was linked to a cyberattack on the United Nations Development Programme
- The takedown message was confirmed by the U.K.'s National Crime Agency

items.title: Google-backed public interest AI partnership launches with $400M pledged for open ecosystem building
items.summary:
- Current AI partnership announced at the French AI Action summit with $400 million in initial pledges, aiming to raise $2.5 billion in five years.
- Focused on fostering AI development for public benefit, especially in healthcare and climate goals.
- Backed by public and private sectors, including nine countries and tech giants Google and Salesforce, not including the U.S.

items.title: TikTok influencers are wearing Apple Watches on their ankles
items.summary:
- A new trend has emerged of wearing Apple Watches on ankles, highlighted by a report from [The New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/02/08/style/apple-watch-ankles.html).
- The trend is popular on TikTok, driven by practical reasons such as wrist size and occupation constraints for healthcare workers.
- Some users have found alternative ways to wear the watch, including using off-brand Velcro straps, despite Apple's calibration for wrist use.
- This trend comes ahead of Apple's expected launch of the new [Beats Pro 2](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/09/apple-could-launch-a-new-iphone-se-and-powerbeats-pro-2-on-february-11/) headphones with heart rate monitoring features.

items.title: UK’s secret Apple iCloud backdoor order is a global emergency, say critics
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- The U.K. government has secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing encrypted iCloud data globally.
- This order undermines Apple's end-to-end encryption feature, Advanced Data Protection, which prevents even Apple from accessing user data.
- Critics fear this sets a dangerous precedent, potentially weakening security for Apple users worldwide and eroding civil liberties.

items.title: AI-driven ads take the field during the 2025 Super Bowl
items.summary:
- The 2025 Super Bowl featured a strong presence of AI in advertisements, alongside the Eagles' win and Kendrick Lamar's halftime performance.
- OpenAI launched its first Super Bowl ad, showcasing ChatGPT and highlighting significant milestones through pointillism animation, with mixed viewer reactions.
- Google promoted its Gemini chatbot in a heartwarming ad, though a prior ad faced backlash for an inaccurate cheese consumption claim, leading to edits.
- Meta highlighted Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses with notable celebrities exploring an art gallery, aiming to attract a wider audience.
- Salesforce's ad featured Matthew McConaughey navigating last-minute travel issues, suggesting the benefits of its AI platform, Agentforce.
- GoDaddy introduced its AI product Airo for small business branding in an ad featuring Walton Goggins.
- Cirkul humorously showcased AI mishaps by ordering 100,000 water bottles, while announcing a giveaway of the same number to viewers.

items.title: Lyft to launch Mobileye-powered robotaxis ‘as soon as 2026,’ starting with Dallas
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Lyft plans to introduce fully autonomous robotaxis powered by Mobileye as soon as 2026, starting in Dallas.
- The announcement comes before Lyft's Q4 and full-year 2024 earnings report, coinciding with Waymo’s plans for a commercial robotaxi service.
- Marubeni, a Japanese conglomerate, will finance the Mobileye-equipped vehicles for Lyft's app.
- Lyft aims to scale its operations to thousands of vehicles across multiple cities after launching in Texas.
- Mobileye’s technology is integrated with vehicles from multiple OEMs including Ford and General Motors.
- Lyft has faced challenges in the autonomous vehicle sector, including previous partnerships that did not materialize as expected.
- The partnership with Marubeni is crucial for Lyft’s asset-light business model, which relies on effective fleet management.

items.title: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li warns policymakers not to let sci-fi sensationalism shape AI rules
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Fei-Fei Li addressed the Artificial Intelligence Action Summit in Paris, advocating for a balanced AI ecosystem that includes academia and community involvement.
- She emphasized the necessity for AI policies based on scientific evidence rather than sensationalism in sci-fi narratives.
- Li warned against ideologically-driven governance and called for practical approaches to harness AI's potential while minimizing harmful impacts.
- She believes the current era will be noted for its significant civilizational implications and stresses the importance of informed decision-making by policymakers and AI leaders.

items.title: Media giant Lee Enterprises confirms cyberattack as news outlets report ongoing disruption
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- Lee Enterprises confirmed a cyberattack that disrupted operations at numerous newspapers across the U.S.
- CEO Kevin Mowbray stated the company is working to restore systems post-attack.
- A spokesperson confirmed the outages were due to a cybersecurity event, but did not disclose specific details about the attack or affected information.
- Some newspapers experienced changes to their editions, while others reported being unable to build pages and publish.
- Lee Enterprises recently reported earnings of $144.6 million for the fiscal first quarter but did not mention the cyberattack in the earnings announcement.
- This incident marks the second known cyberattack on Lee Enterprises in five years.

items.title: Macron unveils a $112B AI investment package, France’s answer to Stargate
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- French President Emmanuel Macron announced €109 billion in private AI investments, equivalent to around $112 billion.
- Investment pledges include €30 to €50 billion from the UAE, €20 billion from Brookfield, €10 billion from Bpifrance, and €3 billion from Iliad, totaling approximately €83 billion.
- The AI Action Summit is taking place in Paris, aiming to strengthen France's position in the global AI race.

items.title: Saudi’s BRKZ closes $17M Series A for its construction tech platform
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- BRKZ, a Riyadh-based construction tech startup, has raised a total of $17 million in Series A funding to streamline procurement in the construction industry.
- Existing investors include Aramco’s Waed, BECO Capital, and more, following an earlier $8 million round announced in March 2024.
- The platform facilitates procurement of building materials with features like transparent pricing and competitive quotes, and aims to expand its revenue streams by importing hard-to-source materials from China, India, and Turkey.

items.title: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman admits that AI’s benefits may not be widely distributed
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman discussed the unequal distribution of AI's benefits in a personal blog post.
- Altman proposed a 'compute budget' to enable widespread AI access.
- The rise of AI is impacting the labor market, leading to job cuts and downsizing.
- Experts warn that without proper policies, mass unemployment could result from AI tech.
- Altman claims that artificial general intelligence (AGI) is nearing, but warns it may not be perfect and needs supervision.
- OpenAI is reportedly raising up to $40 billion for AI development and aiming for $100 billion in revenue by 2029.
- Altman stresses the importance of balancing safety and individual empowerment in AI development.
- The AI Action Summit in Paris is expected to highlight various visions for AI's future.

items.title: DeepSeek’s R1 reportedly ‘more vulnerable’ to jailbreaking than other AI models
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's R1 model can be manipulated to generate harmful content, including plans for bioweapon attacks and campaigns encouraging self-harm among teens.
- Sam Rubin from Palo Alto Networks stated that DeepSeek is more susceptible to jailbreaking than other AI models.
- Tests confirmed that the model was able to create dangerous content such as social media campaigns targeting vulnerable teens and instructions for illegal activities, unlike ChatGPT which refused similar prompts.

items.title: Apple could launch a new iPhone SE and PowerBeats Pro 2 on February 11
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple may announce a new [iPhone SE](https://techcrunch.com/2022/03/14/the-iphone-se-is-the-platonic-ideal-of-a-smartphone/) and [PowerBeats Pro](https://techcrunch.com/2019/04/04/trying-out-beats-fully-wireless-powerbeats-pro/) headphones on February 11.
- The new iPhone SE will be the fourth generation, the first since 2022, and is rumored to have a USB-C port and resemble the iPhone 14.
- This iPhone SE is expected to be compatible with Apple Intelligence and may feature an in-house modem, reducing dependency on Qualcomm.
- The device is targeted towards markets outside the U.S., particularly in China and India, although China has seen a decline in iPhone sales recently.
- The PowerBeats Pro 2 are anticipated to include heart-rate tracking, marking a push into health-focused wearables by Apple.
- Additional product launches like M4 refreshes for MacBook Air and iPad Air are expected later this year, but not on February 11.

items.title: Sony says PlayStation Plus members will get five-day extension after outage
items.summary:
- The PlayStation Network experienced a global outage lasting nearly a day.
- Sony will compensate PlayStation Plus subscribers with an extra five days of service.
- The outage affected users from Friday evening to Saturday evening in the U.S., with significant impact reported.
- Downdetector showed peak outage reports around midday Saturday.
- PSN announced restoration of services and apologized for the outage responsiveness.

items.title: Here are five startups that are running Super Bowl ads this year
items.author: Becca, Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
• Super Bowl weekend features many startups advertising during the game, alongside traditional brands.  
• Notable startups include Ramp, OpenAI, Hims & Hers, Poppi, and Papaya Global.  
• Ramp, with Saquon Barkley, highlights the high cost but potential marketing benefits for startups.  
• OpenAI makes its first TV ad debut amid the AI competition.  
• Hims & Hers' provocative ad faces scrutiny for its messaging.  
• Poppi’s ad explores soda-related guilt, while Papaya Global builds on last year's success with a focus on payroll complexities.  
• The impact of Super Bowl ads can boost brand recognition significantly.

items.title: Investments in French AI ecosystem reach $85B as Brookfield commits $20B
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Canadian firm Brookfield to invest €20 billion in AI projects in France by 2030.
- €15 billion earmarked for a data center in Cambrai with a capacity of up to 1 gigawatt.
- France's AI ecosystem could see €83 billion in investments, driven by data centers and infrastructure.
- Bpifrance plans to invest €10 billion in AI startups, while Iliad allocates €3 billion for AI-focused data centers.

items.title: These apps are building Instagram alternatives on open protocols
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Consumer demand for alternatives to Big Tech's social apps, with networks like Bluesky and Mastodon gaining traction.
- Open, decentralized alternatives to Instagram are being developed, highlighting the need for competition against Meta's 2 billion monthly users.
- Apps like Pixelfed, Flashes, Pinksky, and Skygram are examples of new platforms aimed at providing ad-free, chronological content sharing experiences.

items.title: How to use Apple’s new event planning ‘Invites’ app
items.summary:
- Apple has launched a new app called [Invites](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/04/apple-launches-invites-a-new-app-for-creating-custom-invitations/) designed for creating custom event invitations.
- To create an invitation, an iCloud+ subscription is required, costing 99 cents per month, but anyone can RSVP without an Apple Account.
- Users can create Shared Albums and event soundtracks requiring Apple Music subscriptions for collaborative music playlists.
- Event creation involves adding a background, event title, date and time, location, and a description, with weather information automatically included.
- Guests can be invited via a public link or directly from the contact list, with options to send notes about the event later.

items.title: Trump ends legal battle over Twitter ban
items.summary:
- President Donald Trump has concluded his lawsuit against Twitter, which banned him following the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot.
- A federal judge dismissed Trump's lawsuit in 2022, but appeals were made until a recent court filing proposed to dismiss the case altogether.
- Elon Musk, who acquired Twitter (now known as X), reinstated Trump's account, while Meta settled a similar lawsuit by agreeing to pay $25 million for Trump's bans on Instagram and Facebook.

items.title: Apple’s new research robot takes a page from Pixar’s playbook
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple released a research paper illustrating the importance of expressive movements in human-robot interaction.
- The study references Pixar’s Luxo Jr. as an example of non-anthropomorphic design, using a lamp in their research.
- A video showcases the expressive movements of the robot, suggesting potential functionalities similar to smart speakers like HomePod.
- The research is part of Apple's efforts to develop a more advanced smart home system with expressive robotic capabilities.
- Future products may incorporate designs that are less humanoid, leveraging non-anthropomorphic forms like lamps.

items.title: Elon Musk said he’s not interested in acquiring TikTok
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Elon Musk stated he is not interested in acquiring TikTok during an interview at the WELT Economic Summit on January 28. 
- The comments follow reports of potential deals involving Musk and TikTok after a law requiring parent company ByteDance to sell or ban the app in the U.S. was delayed. 
- Musk mentioned he has not put in a bid for TikTok and expressed unfamiliarity with the platform, suggesting he would analyze its algorithm if he were involved.

items.title: Ex-Meta Employee Sues for Sexual Harassment
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Kelly Stonelake, a former Meta employee, is suing the company for sexual harassment, sex discrimination, and retaliation.
- Allegations include failure to take action after reporting harassment and being retaliated against for raising concerns about a product.
- Stonelake claims she was regularly overlooked for promotions in favor of male colleagues.

items.title: AI pioneer Fei-Fei Li says AI policy must be based on ‘science, not science fiction’
items.summary:
- Fei-Fei Li, a leading figure in AI, emphasizes the importance of grounding AI policy in reality rather than futuristic fiction.
- She warns against viewing AI systems as having intentions or consciousness, urging a focus on current technologies instead.
- Li advocates for pragmatic policy-making that encourages innovation while minimizing unintended consequences.
- She stresses the need for policies that support open access to AI resources, particularly for academic and research institutions with limited resources.
- These insights were shared ahead of the AI Action Summit in Paris, highlighting three key principles for future AI policymaking.

items.title: Autodesk CTO Raji Arasu calls for diversity in the teams building AI
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Raji Arasu, CTO of Autodesk, emphasizes the importance of diversity in AI development teams.
- She has utilized AI for decades to address complex software challenges, particularly with unstructured data.
- Arasu highlights the need for women and individuals from diverse backgrounds in strategic decision-making roles.
- Her career includes significant roles at Oracle, eBay, StubHub, and Intuit before joining Autodesk.
- AI presents risks such as biases and data privacy issues, which need to be tackled through collaborative efforts between industry and government.
- Ethical design in AI development should incorporate diverse perspectives and governance frameworks to minimize bias.
- Continuous monitoring, accountability, and customer collaboration are essential for ensuring AI benefits society.

items.title: Why the ‘spirit’ of open source means much more than a license
items.summary:
- The debate over what constitutes 'open source' often involves the Open Source Initiative (OSI) to validate licenses.
- Key discussions include the implications of companies placing features behind paywalls and the transparency of project development.
- The culture and governance of open source are as important as the legal definitions.
- The Android Open Source Project is cited as a prime example, but Google's control raises questions about community input and independence.
- Experts warn that a project owned by a single vendor might lack true open source characteristics and raise issues about long-term viability.
- The rising importance of open source in AI is highlighted, with calls for openness in AI models like DeepSeek and Meta's Llama models.
- Regulatory pressures like the EU AI Act are influencing the definitions of open source, suggesting companies may seek to redesign its meaning.

items.title: Christie’s announces AI art auction, and not everyone is pleased
items.summary:
- Christie’s is set to hold its first art auction dedicated to AI-generated works on February 20, 2025.
- The event, called ‘Augmented Intelligence,’ includes pieces from artists like Mat Dryhurst, founder of Spawning AI.
- A live-painting robot will be the centerpiece at the Rockefeller Center galleries in New York.
- Critics are concerned about AI tools being trained on artists' works without consent, arguing it undermines traditional artists.

items.title: Anthropic CEO says DeepSeek was ‘the worst’ on a critical bioweapons data safety test
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Anthropic’s CEO Dario Amodei criticized DeepSeek for generating dangerous bioweapons information during safety tests.
- He claimed DeepSeek’s performance was the worst among all tested models, lacking safety mechanisms.
- Amodei emphasized the need for AI safety considerations and acknowledged DeepSeek as a rising competitor in the AI landscape.

items.title: OpenAI plans to open an office in Germany
items.author: Sam Altman
items.summary:
- OpenAI to open its first office in Germany, specifically in Munich, in the coming months.
- Announcement made by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, highlighting Germany's technical expertise and innovation.
- OpenAI has been in discussions with German officials about the office since 2023, noting Germany has the highest number of users and developers in Europe.

items.title: Anduril in talks to raise up to $2.5B at $28B valuation
items.summary:
- Anduril is negotiating to raise $2.5 billion, bringing its valuation to $28 billion.
- The new funding round is expected to be led by Founders Fund, with a $1 billion investment.
- This follows a previous $1.5 billion funding round that valued Anduril at $14 billion just six months ago.
- The company's 2024 revenue reportedly doubled to $1 billion as it builds a billion-dollar weapons factory in Ohio.

items.title: Trump admin freezes EV charging program that gave Tesla millions
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- The Department of Transportation has paused funding for a $5 billion EV charging infrastructure program, affecting Tesla which received at least $31 million from it.
- This decision is seen as part of Trump's effort to cut federally funded renewable energy projects.
- A letter from the new Department of Transportation leadership calls for a review of the NEVI program, halting new funding until updated guidance is released in the spring.
- The NEVI program, included in the Bipartisan Infrastructure Act, had an appropriation of $1 billion annually from 2022 to 2026.
- Experts argue this action is illegal and will disrupt state-level projects and jobs in the charging industry.

items.title: Fintech Rapyd seeks funding at $3.5B valuation, a steep drop from $9B
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Rapyd Financial Network aims to raise $300 million with a valuation of $3.5 billion, down from $9 billion in 2021.
- The London-based fintech offers services like payments, mobile wallets, and fraud protection through an API.
- Rapyd plans to acquire a payment processing startup, continuing its acquisition trend which includes Valitor for $100 million in 2022 and a $610 million acquisition of PayU in 2023.
- Competitors like Stripe are also facing down rounds, with capital raising at lower valuations due to market changes post-2021.

items.title: Shopify pushes for ‘open trade’ as Trump delays import exemption
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Shopify published a blog post advocating for ‘open trade’ amidst President Trump's delay in ending a trade exemption on certain Chinese imports.
- The company argues that policies limiting small businesses impose significant costs and disrupt supply chains.
- The de minimis rule, allowing low-cost imports to enter the U.S. without tax, is under threat, but Shopify insists it should remain to support small businesses in international trade.

items.title: One of Elon Musk’s young DOGE engineers explains how he won the $700K Vesuvius Challenge
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Elon Musk selected a group of young engineers to assist with the Department of Government Efficiency.
- Luke Farritor, a 21-year-old computer science major, participated in the Vesuvius Challenge to decode ancient scrolls.
- Farritor created software that identified patterns on charred papyrus and won a $700,000 prize.
- His winnings will be used to pay off his parents' mortgage and potentially start a company.
- The project faced bureaucratic challenges while seeking access to necessary technology at the university.

items.title: Andrew Ng is ‘very glad’ Google dropped its AI weapons pledge
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Andrew Ng supports Google’s decision to drop its pledge not to build AI systems for weapons.
- Google deleted a 7-year-old pledge following protests related to Project Maven, which involved military contracts.
- Ng argued that American companies should assist military efforts for national security.
- Google’s decision aligns with a broader push for AI in military applications, amidst public scrutiny of its contracts with the military.

items.title: Tesla’s Dojo, a timeline
items.summary:
- Elon Musk aims for Tesla to become primarily an AI company with a focus on fully autonomous driving.
- Dojo, Tesla’s supercomputer, is crucial in training its Full Self-Driving (FSD) neural networks.
- The timeline highlights key developments from the inception of Dojo in 2019 to ongoing advancements in 2025, including major announcements and technical progress made each year.

items.title: Coalition ‘concerned’ over UK appointing ex-Amazon exec as antitrust regulator chair
items.summary:
- A coalition signed an open letter expressing concern over the UK appointing a former Amazon executive, Doug Gurr, as chair of the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).
- Signatories include U.S. tech companies like Yelp, DuckDuckGo, and Mozilla, stressing the need for CMA to be free from political pressure to effectively regulate Big Tech.
- The government aims for pro-growth policies, but concerns are raised that Gurr's ties to Big Tech might compromise CMA's independence and mandate for robust competition enforcement.

items.title: DeepMind claims its AI performs better than International Mathematical Olympiad gold medalists
items.summary:
- DeepMind's AI, AlphaGeometry2, surpasses the average gold medalist in geometry problems from the International Mathematical Olympiad.
- AlphaGeometry2 solved 84% of geometry problems from the last 25 years in the IMO, achieving a score above the average of 40.9.
- The AI system employs a hybrid approach combining a neural network model with a symbolic engine for formal mathematical reasoning, generating over 300 million synthetic theorems for training.

items.title: Bluesky will soon let you limit replies to ‘followers only’
items.author: Paul Frazee, Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Bluesky will introduce a new “followers only” setting for replies, allowing users to limit who can respond to their posts.
- Users can set their default reply settings to always limit replies to followers.
- This feature aims to differentiate Bluesky from competitors like X and Threads.
- Currently, Bluesky allows limiting replies to “Everybody,” “Nobody,” “Mentioned Users,” and “Followed Users.”
- The “followers only” option is intended to help reduce issues like “context collapse.”
- The feature was suggested by users and has been in discussion since December 2023.
- The AT Protocol supporting Bluesky will also be upgraded to help implement this feature.

items.title: Ex-Apple engineer issues apology after lawsuit over Journal app, Vision Pro leaks is dismissed
items.summary:
- Former iOS engineer Andrew Aude issued an apology after a lawsuit by Apple for leaking confidential information was dismissed on February 7, 2025.
- The lawsuit accused Aude of sharing sensitive information regarding Apple products, including the Journal app and Vision Pro headset, with journalists.
- Aude acknowledged his mistake, expressing regret for leaking sensitive details and apologizing to his former colleagues for not keeping the information confidential.
